summary: Email correspondence from a U.S. Attorney's Office co-chief regarding inquiries about potential video footage from inside Jeffrey Epstein's cell after his attempted suicide. The email references Bruce Barket's claims and an interview with Federico Rancier-Medrano, who mentioned a female lieutenant with a video camera.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney who has been insisting that video was taken from inside Epstein's cell after the attempted suicide, though he won't disclose his basis for thinking this.

persons.name: Federico Rancier-Medrano
persons.context: Individual interviewed who stated that a female lieutenant had a video camera with her in the cell when they went back in after Epstein and his cellmate were removed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as 'JE' in the email, the inmate whose cell is the subject of the video inquiry after his attempted suicide.

connections.description: Barket is an attorney making claims about video evidence related to Epstein's cell, suggesting a legal representation or advocacy role.

events.title: Epstein's attempted suicide and cell video inquiry
events.description: Reference to an attempted suicide by Jeffrey Epstein while in custody, followed by inquiries about whether video footage was taken from inside his cell after the incident.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Bruce Barket, an attorney, insisted that video was taken from inside Epstein's cell after his attempted suicide, though he wouldn't disclose his basis for this belief.
Federico Rancier-Medrano stated in an interview that a female lieutenant had a video camera with her in the cell after Epstein and his cellmate were removed.
The email shows ongoing investigation and inquiries by the U.S. Attorney's Office into potential evidence related to Epstein's time in custody.
